column2: The learned man from the cold lands--he was a young man, and seemed to be a clever man--sat in a glowing oven; it took effect on him, he became quite meagre--even his shadow shrunk in, for the sun had also an effect on it.
column3: The learned man from the cold lands-he was a young man, and seemed to be a clever man-sat in a glowing oven; it took effect on him, he became quite meagre-even his shadow shrunk in, for the sun had also an effect on it.

column2: It was first towards evening when the sun was down, that they began to freshen up again.
column3: It was first towards evening when the sun was down, that they began to freshen up again.

column2: In the warm lands every window has a balcony, and the people came out on all the balconies in the street--for one must have air, even if one be accustomed to be mahogany!* It was lively both up and down the street.
column3: In the warm lands every window has a balcony, and the people came out on all the balconies in the street-for one must have air, even if one be accustomed to be mahogany!asterisk It was lively both up and down the street.

column2: Tailors, and shoemakers, and all the folks, moved out into the street--chairs and tables were brought forth--and candles burnt--yes, above a thousand lights were burning--and the one talked and the other sung; and people walked and church-bells rang, and asses went along with a dingle-dingle-dong! for they too had bells on.
column3: Tailors, and shoemakers, and all the folks, moved out into the street-chairs and tables were brought forth-and candles burnt-yes, above a thousand lights were burning-and the one talked and the other sung; and people walked and church bells rang, and asses went along with a dingle dingle dong! for they too had bells on.

column2: The street boys were screaming and hooting, and shouting and shooting, with devils and detonating balls--and there came corpse bearers and hood wearers--for there were funerals with psalm and hymn--and then the din of carriages driving and company arriving: yes, it was, in truth, lively enough down in the street.
column3: The street boys were screaming and hooting, and shouting and shooting, with devils and detonating balls-and there came corpse bearers and hood wearers-for there were funerals with psalm and hymn-and then the din of carriages driving and company arriving: yes, it was, in truth, lively enough down in the street.

column2: Only in that single house, which stood opposite that in which the learned foreigner lived, it was quite still; and yet some one lived there, for there stood flowers in the balcony--they grew so well in the sun's heat! and that they could not do unless they were watered--and some one must water them--there must be somebody there. The door opposite was also opened late in the evening, but it was dark within, at least in the front room; further in there was heard the sound of music.
column3: Only in that single house, which stood opposite that in which the learned foreigner lived, it was quite still; and yet some one lived there, for there stood flowers in the balcony-they grew so well in the sun's heat! and that they could not do unless they were watered-and some one must water them-there must be somebody there. The door opposite was also opened late in the evening, but it was dark within, at least in the front room; further in there was heard the sound of music.

column2: The learned foreigner thought it quite marvellous, but now--it might be that he only imagined it--for he found everything marvellous out there, in the warm lands, if there had only been no sun.
column3: The learned foreigner thought it quite marvellous, but now-it might be that he only imagined it-for he found everything marvellous out there, in the warm lands, if there had only been no sun

column2: The stranger's landlord said that he didn't know who had taken the house opposite, one saw no person about, and as to the music, it appeared to him to be extremely tiresome.
column3: The stranger's landlord said that he didn't know who had taken the house opposite, one saw no person about, and as to the music, it appeared to him to be extremely tiresome.

column2: It is as if some one sat there, and practised a piece that he could not master--always the same piece.	It is as if some one sat there, and practised a piece that he could not master-always the same piece.
column3: true

column2: 'I shall master it!' says he; but yet he cannot master it, however long he plays."
column3: 'I shall master it!' says he; but yet he cannot master it, however long he plays."

column2: * The word mahogany can be understood, in Danish, as having two meanings.
column3: asterisk The word mahogany can be understood, in Danish, as having two meanings.

column2: In general, it means the reddish-brown wood itself; but in jest, it signifies "excessively fine," which arose from an anecdote of Nyboder, in Copenhagen, (the seamen's quarter.) A sailor's wife, who was always proud and fine, in her way, came to her neighbor, and complained that she had got a splinter in her finger.
column3: In general, it means the reddish brown wood itself; but in jest, it signifies "excessively fine," which arose from an anecdote of Nyboder, in Copenhagen, (the seamen's quarter.) A sailor's wife, who was always proud and fine, in her way, came to her neighbor, and complained that she had got a splinter in her finger.

column2: What of? asked the neighbor's wife.
column3: What of? asked the neighbor's wife.

column2: It is a mahogany splinter, said the other.
column3: It is a mahogany splinter, said the other.

column2: Mahogany! It cannot be less with you! exclaimed the woman--and thence the proverb, "It is so mahogany!"--(that is, so excessively fine)--is derived.
column3: Mahogany! It cannot be less with you! exclaimed the woman-and thence the proverb, "It is so mahogany!"--(that is, so excessively fine)--is derived.

column2: One night the stranger awoke--he slept with the doors of the balcony open--the curtain before it was raised by the wind, and he thought that a strange lustre came from the opposite neighbor's house; all the flowers shone like flames, in the most beautiful colors, and in the midst of the flowers stood a slender, graceful maiden--it was as if she also shone; the light really hurt his eyes.
column3: One night the stranger awoke-he slept with the doors of the balcony open-the curtain before it was raised by the wind, and he thought that a strange lustre came from the opposite neighbor's house; all the flowers shone like flames, in the most beautiful colors, and in the midst of the flowers stood a slender, graceful maiden-it was as if she also shone; the light really hurt his eyes.

column2: He now opened them quite wide--yes, he was quite awake; with one spring he was on the floor; he crept gently behind the curtain, but the maiden was gone; the flowers shone no longer, but there they stood, fresh and blooming as ever; the door was ajar, and, far within, the music sounded so soft and delightful, one could really melt away in sweet thoughts from it.
column3: He now opened them quite wide-yes, he was quite awake; with one spring he was on the floor; he crept gently behind the curtain, but the maiden was gone; the flowers shone no longer, but there they stood, fresh and blooming as ever; the door was ajar, and, far within, the music sounded so soft and delightful, one could really melt away in sweet thoughts from it.

column2: Yet it was like a piece of enchantment.
column3: Yet it was like a piece of enchantment.

column2: And who lived there?
column3: And who lived there?

column2: Where was the actual entrance?
column3: Where was the actual entrance?

column2: The whole of the ground-floor was a row of shops, and there people could not always be running through.
column3: The whole of the ground floor was a row of shops, and there people could not always be running through.

column2: One evening the stranger sat out on the balcony.
column3: One evening the stranger sat out on the balcony.

column2: The light burnt in the room behind him; and thus it was quite natural that his shadow should fall on his opposite neighbor's wall.
column3: The light burnt in the room behind him; and thus it was quite natural that his shadow should fall on his opposite neighbor's wall.

column2: Yes! there it sat, directly opposite, between the flowers on the balcony; and when the stranger moved, the shadow also moved: for that it always does.
column3: Yes! there it sat, directly opposite, between the flowers on the balcony; and when the stranger moved, the shadow also moved: for that it always does.

column2: I think my shadow is the only living thing one sees over there, said the learned man.
column3: I think my shadow is the only living thing one sees over there, said the learned man.

column2: See, how nicely it sits between the flowers.	See, how nicely it sits between the flowers.
column3: true

column2: The door stands half-open: now the shadow should be cunning, and go into the room, look about, and then come and tell me what it had seen.
column3: The door stands half open: now the shadow should be cunning, and go into the room, look about, and then come and tell me what it had seen.

column2: Come, now! Be useful, and do me a service," said he, in jest.
column3: Come, now! Be useful, and do me a service," said he, in jest.

column2: Have the kindness to step in.	Have the kindness to step in.
column3: true

column2: Now! Art thou going?" and then he nodded to the shadow, and the shadow nodded again.
column3: Now! Art thou going?" and then he nodded to the shadow, and the shadow nodded again.

column2: Well then, go!	Well then, go!
column3: true

column2: But don't stay away."
column3: But don't stay away."

column2: The stranger rose, and his shadow on the opposite neighbor's balcony rose also; the stranger turned round and the shadow also turned round. Yes! if anyone had paid particular attention to it, they would have seen, quite distinctly, that the shadow went in through the half-open balcony-door of their opposite neighbor, just as the stranger went into his own room, and let the long curtain fall down after him.
column3: The stranger rose, and his shadow on the opposite neighbor's balcony rose also; the stranger turned round and the shadow also turned round. Yes! if anyone had paid particular attention to it, they would have seen, quite distinctly, that the shadow went in through the half open balcony door of their opposite neighbor, just as the stranger went into his own room, and let the long curtain fall down after him.

column2: Next morning, the learned man went out to drink coffee and read the newspapers.
column3: Next morning, the learned man went out to drink coffee and read the newspapers.

column2: What is that? said he, as he came out into the sunshine.
column3: What is that? said he, as he came out into the sunshine.

column2: I have no shadow!	I have no shadow!
column3: true

column2: So then, it has actually gone last night, and not come again.
column3: So then, it has actually gone last night, and not come again.

column2: It is really tiresome!"
column3: It is really tiresome!"

column2: This annoyed him: not so much because the shadow was gone, but because he knew there was a story about a man without a shadow.* It was known to everybody at home, in the cold lands; and if the learned man now came there and told his story, they would say that he was imitating it, and that he had no need to do.
column3: This annoyed him: not so much because the shadow was gone, but because he knew there was a story about a man without a shadow.asterisk It was known to everybody at home, in the cold lands; and if the learned man now came there and told his story, they would say that he was imitating it, and that he had no need to do.

column2: He would, therefore, not talk about it at all; and that was wisely thought.
column3: He would, therefore, not talk about it at all; and that was wisely thought.

column2: *Peter Schlemihl, the shadowless man.
column3: asterisk peter Schlemihl, the shadowless man.

column2: In the evening he went out again on the balcony.
column3: In the evening he went out again on the balcony.

column2: He had placed the light directly behind him, for he knew that the shadow would always have its master for a screen, but he could not entice it.
column3: He had placed the light directly behind him, for he knew that the shadow would always have its master for a screen, but he could not entice it.

column2: He made himself little; he made himself great: but no shadow came again.
column3: He made himself little; he made himself great: but no shadow came again.

column2: He said, "Hem! hem!" but it was of no use.
column3: He said, "Hem! hem!" but it was of no use.

column2: It was vexatious; but in the warm lands everything grows so quickly; and after the lapse of eight days he observed, to his great joy, that a new shadow came in the sunshine.
column3: It was vexatious; but in the warm lands everything grows so quickly; and after the lapse of eight days he observed, to his great joy, that a new shadow came in the sunshine.

column2: In the course of three weeks he had a very fair shadow, which, when he set out for his home in the northern lands, grew more and more in the journey, so that at last it was so long and so large, that it was more than sufficient.
column3: In the course of three weeks he had a very fair shadow, which, when he set out for his home in the northern lands, grew more and more in the journey, so that at last it was so long and so large, that it was more than sufficient.

column2: The learned man then came home, and he wrote books about what was true in the world, and about what was good and what was beautiful; and there passed days and years--yes! many years passed away.
column3: The learned man then came home, and he wrote books about what was true in the world, and about what was good and what was beautiful; and there passed days and years-yes! many years passed away.

column2: One evening, as he was sitting in his room, there was a gentle knocking at the door.
column3: One evening, as he was sitting in his room, there was a gentle knocking at the door.

column2: Come in! said he; but no one came in; so he opened the door, and there stood before him such an extremely lean man, that he felt quite strange. As to the rest, the man was very finely dressed--he must be a gentleman.
column3: Come in! said he; but no one came in; so he opened the door, and there stood before him such an extremely lean man, that he felt quite strange. As to the rest, the man was very finely dressed-he must be a gentleman.

column2: Whom have I the honor of speaking? asked the learned man.
column3: Whom have I the honor of speaking? asked the learned man.

column2: Yes!	Yes!
column3: true

column2: I thought as much," said the fine man.
column3: I thought as much," said the fine man.

column2: I thought you would not know me.	I thought you would not know me.
column3: true

column2: I have got so much body.
column3: I have got so much body.

column2: I have even got flesh and clothes.
column3: I have even got flesh and clothes.

column2: You certainly never thought of seeing me so well off.
column3: You certainly never thought of seeing me so well off.

column2: Do you not know your old shadow?
column3: Do you not know your old shadow?

column2: You certainly thought I should never more return.
column3: You certainly thought I should never more return.

column2: Things have gone on well with me since I was last with you.
column3: Things have gone on well with me since I was last with you.

column2: I have, in all respects, become very well off.
column3: I have, in all respects, become very well off.

column2: Shall I purchase my freedom from service?
column3: Shall I purchase my freedom from service?

column2: If so, I can do it"; and then he rattled a whole bunch of valuable seals that hung to his watch, and he stuck his hand in the thick gold chain he wore around his neck--nay! how all his fingers glittered with diamond rings; and then all were pure gems.
column3: If so, I can do it"; and then he rattled a whole bunch of valuable seals that hung to his watch, and he stuck his hand in the thick gold chain he wore around his neck-nay! how all his fingers glittered with diamond rings; and then all were pure gems.

column2: Nay; I cannot recover from my surprise! said the learned man.
column3: Nay; I cannot recover from my surprise! said the learned man.

column2: What is the meaning of all this?
column3: What is the meaning of all this?

column2: Something common, is it not, said the shadow.
column3: Something common, is it not, said the shadow.

column2: But you yourself do not belong to the common order; and I, as you know well, have from a child followed in your footsteps.	But you yourself do not belong to the common order; and I, as you know well, have from a child followed in your footsteps.
column3: true

column2: As soon as you found I was capable to go out alone in the world, I went my own way.
column3: As soon as you found I was capable to go out alone in the world, I went my own way.

column2: I am in the most brilliant circumstances, but there came a sort of desire over me to see you once more before you die; you will die, I suppose?
column3: I am in the most brilliant circumstances, but there came a sort of desire over me to see you once more before you die; you will die, I suppose?

column2: I also wished to see this land again--for you know we always love our native land.
column3: I also wished to see this land again-for you know we always love our native land.

column2: I know you have got another shadow again; have I anything to pay to it or you?
column3: I know you have got another shadow again; have I anything to pay to it or you?

column2: If so, you will oblige me by saying what it is."
column3: If so, you will oblige me by saying what it is."

column2: Nay, is it really thou? said the learned man.
column3: Nay, is it really thou? said the learned man.

column2: It is most remarkable: I never imagined that one's old shadow could come again as a man.
column3: It is most remarkable: I never imagined that one's old shadow could come again as a man.

column2: Tell me what I have to pay, said the shadow; "for I don't like to be in any sort of debt."
column3: Tell me what I have to pay, said the shadow; "for I don't like to be in any sort of debt."

column2: How canst thou talk so? said the learned man.
column3: How canst thou talk so? said the learned man.

column2: What debt is there to talk about?	What debt is there to talk about?
column3: true

column2: Make thyself as free as anyone else.
column3: Make thyself as free as anyone else.

column2: I am extremely glad to hear of thy good fortune: sit down, old friend, and tell me a little how it has gone with thee, and what thou hast seen at our opposite neighbor's there--in the warm lands."
column3: I am extremely glad to hear of thy good fortune: sit down, old friend, and tell me a little how it has gone with thee, and what thou hast seen at our opposite neighbor's there-in the warm lands."

column2: Yes, I will tell you all about it, said the shadow, and sat down: "but then you must also promise me, that, wherever you may meet me, you will never say to anyone here in the town that I have been your shadow.
column3: Yes, I will tell you all about it, said the shadow, and sat down: "but then you must also promise me, that, wherever you may meet me, you will never say to anyone here in the town that I have been your shadow.

column2: I intend to get betrothed, for I can provide for more than one family."
column3: I intend to get betrothed, for I can provide for more than one family."

column2: Be quite at thy ease about that, said the learned man; "I shall not say to anyone who thou actually art: here is my hand--I promise it, and a man's bond is his word."
column3: Be quite at thy ease about that, said the learned man; "I shall not say to anyone who thou actually art: here is my hand-I promise it, and a man's bond is his word."

column2: A word is a shadow, said the shadow, "and as such it must speak."
column3: A word is a shadow, said the shadow, "and as such it must speak."

column2: It was really quite astonishing how much of a man it was.
column3: It was really quite astonishing how much of a man it was.

column2: It was dressed entirely in black, and of the very finest cloth; it had patent leather boots, and a hat that could be folded together, so that it was bare crown and brim; not to speak of what we already know it had--seals, gold neck-chain, and diamond rings; yes, the shadow was well-dressed, and it was just that which made it quite a man.
column3: It was dressed entirely in black, and of the very finest cloth; it had patent leather boots, and a hat that could be folded together, so that it was bare crown and brim; not to speak of what we already know it had-seals, gold neck chain, and diamond rings; yes, the shadow was well dressed, and it was just that which made it quite a man.

column2: Now I shall tell you my adventures, said the shadow; and then he sat, with the polished boots, as heavily as he could, on the arm of the learned man's new shadow, which lay like a poodle-dog at his feet. Now this was perhaps from arrogance; and the shadow on the ground kept itself so still and quiet, that it might hear all that passed: it wished to know how it could get free, and work its way up, so as to become its own master.
column3: Now I shall tell you my adventures, said the shadow; and then he sat, with the polished boots, as heavily as he could, on the arm of the learned man's new shadow, which lay like a poodle dog at his feet. Now this was perhaps from arrogance; and the shadow on the ground kept itself so still and quiet, that it might hear all that passed: it wished to know how it could get free, and work its way up, so as to become its own master.

column2: Do you know who lived in our opposite neighbor's house? said the shadow.
column3: Do you know who lived in our opposite neighbor's house? said the shadow.

column2: It was the most charming of all beings, it was Poesy!	It was the most charming of all beings, it was Poesy!
column3: true

column2: I was there for three weeks, and that has as much effect as if one had lived three thousand years, and read all that was composed and written; that is what I say, and it is right.
column3: I was there for three weeks, and that has as much effect as if one had lived three thousand years, and read all that was composed and written; that is what I say, and it is right.

column2: I have seen everything and I know everything!"
column3: I have seen everything and I know everything!"

column2: Poesy! cried the learned man.
column3: Poesy! cried the learned man.

column2: Yes, yes, she often dwells a recluse in large cities!	Yes, yes, she often dwells a recluse in large cities!
column3: true

column2: Poesy!
column3: Poesy!

column2: Yes, I have seen her--a single short moment, but sleep came into my eyes!
column3: Yes, I have seen her-a single short moment, but sleep came into my eyes!

column2: She stood on the balcony and shone as the Aurora Borealis shines.
column3: She stood on the balcony and shone as the Aurora Borealis shines.

column2: Go on, go on--thou wert on the balcony, and went through the doorway, and then--"
column3: Go on, go on-thou wert on the balcony, and went through the doorway, and then-"

column2: Then I was in the antechamber, said the shadow.
column3: Then I was in the antechamber, said the shadow.

column2: You always sat and looked over to the antechamber.	You always sat and looked over to the antechamber.
column3: true

column2: There was no light; there was a sort of twilight, but the one door stood open directly opposite the other through a long row of rooms and saloons, and there it was lighted up.
column3: There was no light; there was a sort of twilight, but the one door stood open directly opposite the other through a long row of rooms and saloons, and there it was lighted up.

column2: I should have been completely killed if I had gone over to the maiden; but I was circumspect, I took time to think, and that one must always do."
column3: I should have been completely killed if I had gone over to the maiden; but I was circumspect, I took time to think, and that one must always do."

column2: And what didst thou then see? asked the learned man.
column3: And what didst thou then see? asked the learned man.

column2: I saw everything, and I shall tell all to you: but--it is no pride on my part--as a free man, and with the knowledge I have, not to speak of my position in life, my excellent circumstances--I certainly wish that you would say YOU* to me!
column3: I saw everything, and I shall tell all to you: but-it is no pride on my part-as a free man, and with the knowledge I have, not to speak of my position in life, my excellent circumstances-I certainly wish that you would say YOU asterisk to me!

column2: * It is the custom in Denmark for intimate acquaintances to use the second person singular, "Du," (thou) when speaking to each other.
column3: asterisk It is the custom in Denmark for intimate acquaintances to use the second person singular, "Du," (thou) when speaking to each other.

column2: When a friendship is formed between men, they generally affirm it, when occasion offers, either in public or private, by drinking to each other and exclaiming, "thy health," at the same time striking their glasses together.
column3: When a friendship is formed between men, they generally affirm it, when occasion offers, either in public or private, by drinking to each other and exclaiming, "thy health," at the same time striking their glasses together.

column2: This is called drinking "Duus": they are then, "Duus Brodre," (thou brothers) and ever afterwards use the pronoun "thou," to each other, it being regarded as more familiar than "De," (you).
column3: This is called drinking "Duus": they are then, "Duus Brodre," (thou brothers) and ever afterwards use the pronoun "thou," to each other, it being regarded as more familiar than "De," (you).

column2: Father and mother, sister and brother say thou to one another--without regard to age or rank.
column3: Father and mother, sister and brother say thou to one another-without regard to age or rank.

column2: Master and mistress say thou to their servants the superior to the inferior.
column3: Master and mistress say thou to their servants the superior to the inferior.

column2: But servants and inferiors do not use the same term to their masters, or superiors--nor is it ever used when speaking to a stranger, or anyone with whom they are but slightly acquainted--they then say as in English--you.
column3: But servants and inferiors do not use the same term to their masters, or superiors-nor is it ever used when speaking to a stranger, or anyone with whom they are but slightly acquainted-they then say as in English-you.

column2: I beg your pardon, said the learned man; "it is an old habit with me. YOU are perfectly right, and I shall remember it; but now you must tell me all YOU saw!"
column3: I beg your pardon, said the learned man; "it is an old habit with me. YOU are perfectly right, and I shall remember it; but now you must tell me all YOU saw!"

column2: Everything! said the shadow.
column3: Everything! said the shadow.

column2: For I saw everything, and I know everything!
column3: For I saw everything, and I know everything!

column2: How did it look in the furthest saloon? asked the learned man.
column3: How did it look in the furthest saloon? asked the learned man.

column2: Was it there as in the fresh woods?	Was it there as in the fresh woods?
column3: true

column2: Was it there as in a holy church?
column3: Was it there as in a holy church?

column2: Were the saloons like the starlit firmament when we stand on the high mountains?"
column3: Were the saloons like the starlit firmament when we stand on the high mountains?"

column2: Everything was there! said the shadow.
column3: Everything was there! said the shadow.

column2: I did not go quite in, I remained in the foremost room, in the twilight, but I stood there quite well; I saw everything, and I know everything!	I did not go quite in, I remained in the foremost room, in the twilight, but I stood there quite well; I saw everything, and I know everything!
column3: true

column2: I have been in the antechamber at the court of Poesy."
column3: I have been in the antechamber at the court of Poesy."

column2: But WHAT DID you see?	But WHAT DID you see?
column3: true

column2: Did all the gods of the olden times pass through the large saloons?
column3: Did all the gods of the olden times pass through the large saloons?

column2: Did the old heroes combat there?
column3: Did the old heroes combat there?

column2: Did sweet children play there, and relate their dreams?"
column3: Did sweet children play there, and relate their dreams?"

column2: I tell you I was there, and you can conceive that I saw everything there was to be seen.	I tell you I was there, and you can conceive that I saw everything there was to be seen.
column3: true

column2: Had you come over there, you would not have been a man; but I became so!
column3: Had you come over there, you would not have been a man; but I became so!

column2: And besides, I learned to know my inward nature, my innate qualities, the relationship I had with Poesy.
column3: And besides, I learned to know my inward nature, my innate qualities, the relationship I had with Poesy.

column2: At the time I was with you, I thought not of that, but always--you know it well--when the sun rose, and when the sun went down, I became so strangely great; in the moonlight I was very near being more distinct than yourself; at that time I did not understand my nature; it was revealed to me in the antechamber!
column3: At the time I was with you, I thought not of that, but always-you know it well-when the sun rose, and when the sun went down, I became so strangely great; in the moonlight I was very near being more distinct than yourself; at that time I did not understand my nature; it was revealed to me in the antechamber!

column2: I became a man!
column3: I became a man!

column2: I came out matured; but you were no longer in the warm lands; as a man I was ashamed to go as I did.
column3: I came out matured; but you were no longer in the warm lands; as a man I was ashamed to go as I did.

column2: I was in want of boots, of clothes, of the whole human varnish that makes a man perceptible.
column3: I was in want of boots, of clothes, of the whole human varnish that makes a man perceptible.

column2: I took my way--I tell it to you, but you will not put it in any book--I took my way to the cake woman--I hid myself behind her; the woman didn't think how much she concealed.
column3: I took my way-I tell it to you, but you will not put it in any book-I took my way to the cake woman-I hid myself behind her; the woman didn't think how much she concealed.

column2: I went out first in the evening; I ran about the streets in the moonlight; I made myself long up the walls--it tickles the back so delightfully!
column3: I went out first in the evening; I ran about the streets in the moonlight; I made myself long up the walls-it tickles the back so delightfully!

column2: I ran up, and ran down, peeped into the highest windows, into the saloons, and on the roofs, I peeped in where no one could peep, and I saw what no one else saw, what no one else should see!
column3: I ran up, and ran down, peeped into the highest windows, into the saloons, and on the roofs, I peeped in where no one could peep, and I saw what no one else saw, what no one else should see!

column2: This is, in fact, a base world!
column3: This is, in fact, a base world!

column2: I would not be a man if it were not now once accepted and regarded as something to be so! I saw the most unimaginable things with the women, with the men, with parents, and with the sweet, matchless children; I saw," said the shadow, "what no human being must know, but what they would all so willingly know--what is bad in their neighbor.
column3: I would not be a man if it were not now once accepted and regarded as something to be so! I saw the most unimaginable things with the women, with the men, with parents, and with the sweet, matchless children; I saw," said the shadow, "what no human being must know, but what they would all so willingly know-what is bad in their neighbor.

column2: Had I written a newspaper, it would have been read!
column3: Had I written a newspaper, it would have been read!

column2: But I wrote direct to the persons themselves, and there was consternation in all the towns where I came. They were so afraid of me, and yet they were so excessively fond of me.
column3: But I wrote direct to the persons themselves, and there was consternation in all the towns where I came. They were so afraid of me, and yet they were so excessively fond of me.

column2: The professors made a professor of me; the tailors gave me new clothes--I am well furnished; the master of the mint struck new coin for me, and the women said I was so handsome!
column3: The professors made a professor of me; the tailors gave me new clothes-I am well furnished; the master of the mint struck new coin for me, and the women said I was so handsome!

column2: And so I became the man I am. And I now bid you farewell.
column3: And so I became the man I am. And I now bid you farewell.

column2: Here is my card--I live on the sunny side of the street, and am always at home in rainy weather!" And so away went the shadow.
column3: Here is my card-I live on the sunny side of the street, and am always at home in rainy weather!" And so away went the shadow.

column2: That was most extraordinary! said the learned man.
column3: That was most extraordinary! said the learned man.

column2: Years and days passed away, then the shadow came again.
column3: Years and days passed away, then the shadow came again.

column2: How goes it? said the shadow.
column3: How goes it? said the shadow.

column2: Alas! said the learned man.
column3: Alas! said the learned man.

column2: I write about the true, and the good, and the beautiful, but no one cares to hear such things; I am quite desperate, for I take it so much to heart!
column3: I write about the true, and the good, and the beautiful, but no one cares to hear such things; I am quite desperate, for I take it so much to heart!

column2: But I don't! said the shadow.
column3: But I don't! said the shadow.

column2: I become fat, and it is that one wants to become!	I become fat, and it is that one wants to become!
column3: true

column2: You do not understand the world.
column3: You do not understand the world.

column2: You will become ill by it. You must travel!
column3: You will become ill by it. You must travel!

column2: I shall make a tour this summer; will you go with me? I should like to have a travelling companion!
column3: I shall make a tour this summer; will you go with me? I should like to have a travelling companion!

column2: Will you go with me, as shadow?
column3: Will you go with me, as shadow?

column2: It will be a great pleasure for me to have you with me; I shall pay the travelling expenses!"
column3: It will be a great pleasure for me to have you with me; I shall pay the travelling expenses!"

column2: Nay, this is too much! said the learned man.
column3: Nay, this is too much! said the learned man.

column2: It is just as one takes it! said the shadow.
column3: It is just as one takes it! said the shadow.

column2: It will do you much good to travel!	It will do you much good to travel!
column3: true

column2: Will you be my shadow?
column3: Will you be my shadow?

column2: You shall have everything free on the journey!"
column3: You shall have everything free on the journey!"

column2: Nay, that is too bad! said the learned man.
column3: Nay, that is too bad! said the learned man.

column2: But it is just so with the world! said the shadow, "and so it will be!" and away it went again.
column3: But it is just so with the world! said the shadow, "and so it will be!" and away it went again.

column2: The learned man was not at all in the most enviable state; grief and torment followed him, and what he said about the true, and the good, and the beautiful, was, to most persons, like roses for a cow!
column3: The learned man was not at all in the most enviable state; grief and torment followed him, and what he said about the true, and the good, and the beautiful, was, to most persons, like roses for a cow!

column2: He was quite ill at last.
column3: He was quite ill at last.

column2: You really look like a shadow! said his friends to him; and the learned man trembled, for he thought of it.
column3: You really look like a shadow! said his friends to him; and the learned man trembled, for he thought of it.

column2: You must go to a watering-place! said the shadow, who came and visited him.
column3: You must go to a watering place! said the shadow, who came and visited him.

column2: There is nothing else for it!	There is nothing else for it!
column3: true

column2: I will take you with me for old acquaintance' sake; I will pay the travelling expenses, and you write the descriptions--and if they are a little amusing for me on the way! I will go to a watering-place--my beard does not grow out as it ought--that is also a sickness--and one must have a beard!
column3: I will take you with me for old acquaintance' sake; I will pay the travelling expenses, and you write the descriptions-and if they are a little amusing for me on the way! I will go to a watering place-my beard does not grow out as it ought-that is also a sickness-and one must have a beard!

column2: Now you be wise and accept the offer; we shall travel as comrades!"
column3: Now you be wise and accept the offer; we shall travel as comrades!"

column2: And so they travelled; the shadow was master, and the master was the shadow; they drove with each other, they rode and walked together, side by side, before and behind, just as the sun was; the shadow always took care to keep itself in the master's place.
column3: And so they travelled; the shadow was master, and the master was the shadow; they drove with each other, they rode and walked together, side by side, before and behind, just as the sun was; the shadow always took care to keep itself in the master's place.

column2: Now the learned man didn't think much about that; he was a very kind-hearted man, and particularly mild and friendly, and so he said one day to the shadow: "As we have now become companions, and in this way have grown up together from childhood, shall we not drink 'thou' together, it is more familiar?"
column3: Now the learned man didn't think much about that; he was a very kind hearted man, and particularly mild and friendly, and so he said one day to the shadow: "As we have now become companions, and in this way have grown up together from childhood, shall we not drink 'thou' together, it is more familiar?"

column2: You are right, said the shadow, who was now the proper master.
column3: You are right, said the shadow, who was now the proper master.

column2: It is said in a very straight-forward and well-meant manner.	It is said in a very straight forward and well meant manner.
column3: true

column2: You, as a learned man, certainly know how strange nature is.
column3: You, as a learned man, certainly know how strange nature is.

column2: Some persons cannot bear to touch grey paper, or they become ill; others shiver in every limb if one rub a pane of glass with a nail: I have just such a feeling on hearing you say thou to me; I feel myself as if pressed to the earth in my first situation with you.
column3: Some persons cannot bear to touch grey paper, or they become ill; others shiver in every limb if one rub a pane of glass with a nail: I have just such a feeling on hearing you say thou to me; I feel myself as if pressed to the earth in my first situation with you.

column2: You see that it is a feeling; that it is not pride: I cannot allow you to say THOU to me, but I will willingly say THOU to you, so it is half done!"
column3: You see that it is a feeling; that it is not pride: I cannot allow you to say THOU to me, but I will willingly say THOU to you, so it is half done!"

column2: So the shadow said THOU to its former master.
column3: So the shadow said THOU to its former master.

column2: This is rather too bad, thought he, "that I must say YOU and he say THOU," but he was now obliged to put up with it.
column3: This is rather too bad, thought he, "that I must say YOU and he say THOU," but he was now obliged to put up with it.

column2: So they came to a watering-place where there were many strangers, and amongst them was a princess, who was troubled with seeing too well; and that was so alarming!
column3: So they came to a watering place where there were many strangers, and amongst them was a princess, who was troubled with seeing too well; and that was so alarming!

column2: She directly observed that the stranger who had just come was quite a different sort of person to all the others; "He has come here in order to get his beard to grow, they say, but I see the real cause, he cannot cast a shadow."
column3: She directly observed that the stranger who had just come was quite a different sort of person to all the others; "He has come here in order to get his beard to grow, they say, but I see the real cause, he cannot cast a shadow."

column2: She had become inquisitive; and so she entered into conversation directly with the strange gentleman, on their promenades.
column3: She had become inquisitive; and so she entered into conversation directly with the strange gentleman, on their promenades.

column2: As the daughter of a king, she needed not to stand upon trifles, so she said, "Your complaint is, that you cannot cast a shadow?"
column3: As the daughter of a king, she needed not to stand upon trifles, so she said, "Your complaint is, that you cannot cast a shadow?"

column2: Your Royal Highness must be improving considerably, said the shadow, "I know your complaint is, that you see too clearly, but it has decreased, you are cured.
column3: Your Royal Highness must be improving considerably, said the shadow, "I know your complaint is, that you see too clearly, but it has decreased, you are cured.

column2: I just happen to have a very unusual shadow! Do you not see that person who always goes with me?
column3: I just happen to have a very unusual shadow! Do you not see that person who always goes with me?

column2: Other persons have a common shadow, but I do not like what is common to all.
column3: Other persons have a common shadow, but I do not like what is common to all.

column2: We give our servants finer cloth for their livery than we ourselves use, and so I had my shadow trimmed up into a man: yes, you see I have even given him a shadow.
column3: We give our servants finer cloth for their livery than we ourselves use, and so I had my shadow trimmed up into a man: yes, you see I have even given him a shadow.

column2: It is somewhat expensive, but I like to have something for myself!"
column3: It is somewhat expensive, but I like to have something for myself!"

column2: What! thought the princess.
column3: What! thought the princess.

column2: Should I really be cured!	Should I really be cured!
column3: true

column2: These baths are the first in the world!
column3: These baths are the first in the world!

column2: In our time water has wonderful powers.
column3: In our time water has wonderful powers.

column2: But I shall not leave the place, for it now begins to be amusing here.
column3: But I shall not leave the place, for it now begins to be amusing here.

column2: I am extremely fond of that stranger: would that his beard should not grow, for in that case he will leave us!"
column3: I am extremely fond of that stranger: would that his beard should not grow, for in that case he will leave us!"

column2: In the evening, the princess and the shadow danced together in the large ball-room.
column3: In the evening, the princess and the shadow danced together in the large ball room.

column2: She was light, but he was still lighter; she had never had such a partner in the dance.
column3: She was light, but he was still lighter; she had never had such a partner in the dance.

column2: She told him from what land she came, and he knew that land; he had been there, but then she was not at home; he had peeped in at the window, above and below--he had seen both the one and the other, and so he could answer the princess, and make insinuations, so that she was quite astonished; he must be the wisest man in the whole world!
column3: She told him from what land she came, and he knew that land; he had been there, but then she was not at home; he had peeped in at the window, above and below-he had seen both the one and the other, and so he could answer the princess, and make insinuations, so that she was quite astonished; he must be the wisest man in the whole world!

column2: She felt such respect for what he knew!
column3: She felt such respect for what he knew!

column2: So that when they again danced together she fell in love with him; and that the shadow could remark, for she almost pierced him through with her eyes. So they danced once more together; and she was about to declare herself, but she was discreet; she thought of her country and kingdom, and of the many persons she would have to reign over.
column3: So that when they again danced together she fell in love with him; and that the shadow could remark, for she almost pierced him through with her eyes. So they danced once more together; and she was about to declare herself, but she was discreet; she thought of her country and kingdom, and of the many persons she would have to reign over.

column2: He is a wise man, said she to herself--"It is well; and he dances delightfully--that is also good; but has he solid knowledge?
column3: He is a wise man, said she to herself-"It is well; and he dances delightfully-that is also good; but has he solid knowledge?

column2: That is just as important!
column3: That is just as important!

column2: He must be examined."
column3: He must be examined."

column2: So she began, by degrees, to question him about the most difficult things she could think of, and which she herself could not have answered; so that the shadow made a strange face.
column3: So she began, by degrees, to question him about the most difficult things she could think of, and which she herself could not have answered; so that the shadow made a strange face.

column2: You cannot answer these questions? said the princess.
column3: You cannot answer these questions? said the princess.

column2: They belong to my childhood's learning, said the shadow.
column3: They belong to my childhood's learning, said the shadow.

column2: I really believe my shadow, by the door there, can answer them!
column3: I really believe my shadow, by the door there, can answer them!

column2: Your shadow! said the princess.
column3: Your shadow! said the princess.

column2: That would indeed be marvellous!
column3: That would indeed be marvellous!

column2: I will not say for a certainty that he can, said the shadow, "but I think so; he has now followed me for so many years, and listened to my conversation--I should think it possible.
column3: I will not say for a certainty that he can, said the shadow, "but I think so; he has now followed me for so many years, and listened to my conversation-I should think it possible.

column2: But your royal highness will permit me to observe, that he is so proud of passing himself off for a man, that when he is to be in a proper humor--and he must be so to answer well--he must be treated quite like a man."
column3: But your royal highness will permit me to observe, that he is so proud of passing himself off for a man, that when he is to be in a proper humor-and he must be so to answer well-he must be treated quite like a man."

column2: Oh!	Oh!
column3: false

column2: I like that!" said the princess.
column3: I like that!" said the princess.

column2: So she went to the learned man by the door, and she spoke to him about the sun and the moon, and about persons out of and in the world, and he answered with wisdom and prudence.
column3: So she went to the learned man by the door, and she spoke to him about the sun and the moon, and about persons out of and in the world, and he answered with wisdom and prudence.

column2: What a man that must be who has so wise a shadow! thought she.
column3: What a man that must be who has so wise a shadow! thought she.

column2: It will be a real blessing to my people and kingdom if I choose him for my consort--I will do it!
column3: It will be a real blessing to my people and kingdom if I choose him for my consort-I will do it!

column2: They were soon agreed, both the princess and the shadow; but no one was to know about it before she arrived in her own kingdom.
column3: They were soon agreed, both the princess and the shadow; but no one was to know about it before she arrived in her own kingdom.

column2: No one--not even my shadow! said the shadow, and he had his own thoughts about it!
column3: No one-not even my shadow! said the shadow, and he had his own thoughts about it!

column2: Now they were in the country where the princess reigned when she was at home.
column3: Now they were in the country where the princess reigned when she was at home.

column2: Listen, my good friend, said the shadow to the learned man.
column3: Listen, my good friend, said the shadow to the learned man.

column2: I have now become as happy and mighty as anyone can be; I will, therefore, do something particular for thee!	I have now become as happy and mighty as anyone can be; I will, therefore, do something particular for thee!
column3: true

column2: Thou shalt always live with me in the palace, drive with me in my royal carriage, and have ten thousand pounds a year; but then thou must submit to be called SHADOW by all and everyone; thou must not say that thou hast ever been a man; and once a year, when I sit on the balcony in the sunshine, thou must lie at my feet, as a shadow shall do!
column3: Thou shalt always live with me in the palace, drive with me in my royal carriage, and have ten thousand pounds a year; but then thou must submit to be called SHADOW by all and everyone; thou must not say that thou hast ever been a man; and once a year, when I sit on the balcony in the sunshine, thou must lie at my feet, as a shadow shall do!

column2: I must tell thee: I am going to marry the king's daughter, and the nuptials are to take place this evening!"
column3: I must tell thee: I am going to marry the king's daughter, and the nuptials are to take place this evening!"

column2: Nay, this is going too far! said the learned man.
column3: Nay, this is going too far! said the learned man.

column2: I will not have it; I will not do it!	I will not have it; I will not do it!
column3: true

column2: It is to deceive the whole country and the princess too!
column3: It is to deceive the whole country and the princess too!

column2: I will tell everything!
column3: I will tell everything!

column2: That I am a man, and that thou art a shadow--thou art only dressed up!"
column3: That I am a man, and that thou art a shadow-thou art only dressed up!"

column2: There is no one who will believe it! said the shadow.
column3: There is no one who will believe it! said the shadow.

column2: Be reasonable, or I will call the guard!
column3: Be reasonable, or I will call the guard!

column2: I will go directly to the princess! said the learned man.
column3: I will go directly to the princess! said the learned man.

column2: But I will go first! said the shadow.
column3: But I will go first! said the shadow.

column2: And thou wilt go to prison! and that he was obliged to do--for the sentinels obeyed him whom they knew the king's daughter was to marry.
column3: And thou wilt go to prison! and that he was obliged to do-for the sentinels obeyed him whom they knew the king's daughter was to marry.

column2: You tremble! said the princess, as the shadow came into her chamber. "Has anything happened?
column3: You tremble! said the princess, as the shadow came into her chamber. "Has anything happened?

column2: You must not be unwell this evening, now that we are to have our nuptials celebrated."
column3: You must not be unwell this evening, now that we are to have our nuptials celebrated."

column2: I have lived to see the most cruel thing that anyone can live to see! said the shadow.
column3: I have lived to see the most cruel thing that anyone can live to see! said the shadow.

column2: Only imagine--yes, it is true, such a poor shadow-skull cannot bear much--only think, my shadow has become mad; he thinks that he is a man, and that I--now only think--that I am his shadow!
column3: Only imagine-yes, it is true, such a poor shadow skull cannot bear much-only think, my shadow has become mad; he thinks that he is a man, and that I-now only think-that I am his shadow!

column2: It is terrible! said the princess; "but he is confined, is he not?"
column3: It is terrible! said the princess; "but he is confined, is he not?"

column2: That he is.	That he is.
column3: true

column2: I am afraid that he will never recover."
column3: I am afraid that he will never recover."

column2: Poor shadow! said the princess.
column3: Poor shadow! said the princess.

column2: He is very unfortunate; it would be a real work of charity to deliver him from the little life he has, and, when I think properly over the matter, I am of opinion that it will be necessary to do away with him in all stillness!
column3: He is very unfortunate; it would be a real work of charity to deliver him from the little life he has, and, when I think properly over the matter, I am of opinion that it will be necessary to do away with him in all stillness!
